metadata.title: Nano assembly of N-doped graphene quantum dots anchored Fe3O4/halloysite nanotubes for high performance supercapacitor

sections.text:
Nano assembly of N-doped graphene quantum dots anchored Fe3O4/ halloysite nanotubes for high performance supercapacitor
Akhilesh Babu Ganganboinaa, Ankan Dutta Chowdhuryb, Ruey-an Doonga,b,* aDepartment of Biomedical Engineering and Environmental Sciences, National Tsing Hua University, 101 Section 2, Kuang-Fu Road, Hsinchu, 30013, Taiwan b Institute of Environmental Engineering, National Chiao Tung University, 1001 University Road, Hsinchu, 30010, Taiwan
A R T I C L E I N F O
Article history: Received 17 March 2017 Received in revised form 17 May 2017 Accepted 1 June 2017 Available online 3 June 2017
Keywords: Fe3O4 halloysite capacitor power density energy density fabrication
A B S T R A C T
The development of robust and low cost electrode materials with superior electrochemical properties has been a subject of focus on energy storage devices. Herein, the development of N-doped graphene quantum dots (N-GQDs) deposited on Fe3O4-halloysite nanotubes (Fe3O4-HNTs) as active anode materials has been established for supercapacitor applications. The Fe3O4 nanoparticles synthesised by coprecipitation have been in-situ deposited on HNT surfaces following by the coating of (3- aminopropyl)-triexthoxysilane to anchor 4–10 nm N-GQDs via the formation of amide linkage. The N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs exhibits a high specific capacitance of 418 F g 1 and maintains good rate capability in neutral electrolyte solutions. In addition, the anode materials show excellent electrochemical performance with energy and power densities of 10.4–29 W h kg 1 and 0.25–5.2 kW kg 1, respectively. Such excellent electrochemical features can be attributed to the synergistic contribution from individual components. The Fe3O4-HNTs provide 1-dimensional matrix to shorten the diffusion path of electrons and electrolyte ions as well as to absorb the mechanical stress during cycling along with excess sites for charge storage, while N-GQDs offer abundantly accessible electroactive sites for rapid electrons and electrolyte ions transport as well as enhance electrical conductivity of Fe3O4-HNTs. Results obtained in this study clearly demonstrate that metal oxide-HNTs are promising support to anchor N-GQDs nanomaterials as the high performance anode materials for next generation of energy storage devices with high energy and power densities.

Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Electrochimica Acta
journal homepa ge: www.elsev ier .com/locate /e lectacta

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
With the technological advancements in sectors and continuous depletion of conventional sources of energy, a parallel demand for green and safe energy has significantly increased. There is an urgent need for energy storage devices with longetivity and high performance characteristics which can meet the demand of energy [1]. Presently, lithium ion batteries and supercapacitors have been the alternatives which are able to fulfil the criteria of modern technology because of their high cycle life, portability, environmental stability and user friendliness along with their high electrochemical performance [2]. However, there also exists a continuous thirst to improve the electrochemical performance of such systems by incorporating novel hybrid nanomaterials. The performance of supercapacitor is highly influenced by the
* Corresponding author at: Institute of Environmental Engineering, National Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan.
E-mail address: radoong@mx.nthu.edu.tw (R.-a. Doong).
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.electacta.2017.06.002 0013-4686/© 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
feasibility of formation of electrical double layers and the storage of charge [3,4]. Therefore, a great deal of recent research effort has been placed on the combination of carbon materials with the pseudo-capacitive materials that can exert both double layer capacitor characteristics and faradaic pseudocapacitor property for enhanced electrochemical performance.
Over the past decades, much attention has been focused on carbon allotropes as efficient electrode materials for supercapacitor applications. Graphene quantum dots (GQDs), a zerodimensional allotrope of graphitic carbon, have emerged as the newly developed potential member of graphene family [5]. GQDs have several unique advantages including the tailorable surface features, tunable bandgaps, excellent electrical and photo-physical features, making this allotrope a multifaceted nanomaterial for a wide variety of applications [6,7]. GQDs have been used in biosensors, drug carriers, nuclear targeted drug delivery and also emerged as a useful electrochemical material for energy conversion and storage [8–11]. The combination of GQDs with certain transition metal compounds have also been reported as efficient electrode materials. Several studies have used GQD-based
nanomaterials as the electrode materials for electrochemical application [5,7,12]. Liu et al. fabricated GQDs//MnO2 asymmetric micro-supercapacitor which displays higher specific capacitance of 1107 mF cm 2 [5]. Nanocomposites of VO2 and MoS2 were combined with GQDs to enhance the structural and compositional advantages for high-performance lithium ions storage, including expanded interlayer distances and fast electrochemical reactions [13,14]. Chen et al. have developed GQD-3 dimensional graphene composites for supercapacitor application and found that the optimal specific capacitance was 268 F g 1 at a current density of 1.25 A g 1. In addition, N-doped grapheme family has been demonstrated to be excellent materials for enhanced electrochemical performance. N-doped GQDs (N-GQDs) has been used as the electrolytes for supercapacitors and found that N-GQD electrolytes exhibited markedly superior capacitance and rate performance [12]. These exquisite properties make N-GQDs a promising nanomaterial to combine with metal oxides for high capacitive performance.
In addition to carbon-based nanomaterials, metal oxides in nanocomposites have been reported to be good electrode materials for energy conversion and storage applications which can contribute the high energy density from storing the charge of redox reactions [15–18]. Transition metal oxides are chemically stable and mechanically strong to be used as electrodes in long cycling systems. Among the various transition metal oxides used, magnetic Fe3O4 has been widely studied because of its variable oxidation states, nature abundance, low cost and easy recycling [19,20]. The combination of graphene-based nanomaterials also enhances the capacitance, energy storage ability and rate capability [21,22]. A high specific capacitance of 241 F g 1 was obtained when Fe3O4 nanoparticles were anchored on 2-dimensional reduced graphene composites [23] and graphene sheet/ Fe3O4 paper could achieve a high specific capacitance of 368 F g 1 [24]. However, the fabrication as well as electrochemical performance of N-GQDs with Fe3O4 in the presence of 1-dimensional nanomaterials as the promising anode materials for supercapacitor application has not been reported yet.
Herein, the electrochemical performance of N-GQDs anchored on the surface of Fe3O4-halloysite nanotubes (HNTs) for supercapacitor application has been investigated. HNTs are 1-D nanotubular structures composed of (Al, Si) oxides with an outer diameter of 50 100 nm, net negative charge, and economically benefit [25]. The large surface area and high porosity makes HNTs a promising support for uniform dispersion of N-GQD@Fe3O4 onto the surface as well as for rapid storage of electrons to achieve high specific capacitance along with improved cycle life. The presence of N-GQDs improves the power density as well as offers electrical and mechanical stability to the nanocomposites, while Fe3O4 increase the energy density. Results show that N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNT nanocomposites is a highly potential and promising supercapacitor electrode material with high specific capacitance of 418 F g 1 at 0.5 A g 1, excellent rate capability, and long-term cycling stability after 3000 cycle in 1 M Na2SO4 electrolyte. Results obtained in this study can open a new avenue by using metal oxide-HNTs as the promising support to anchor N-GQDs nanomaterials for high performance energy storage devices with excellent energy and power densities.

sections.heading: 2.1. Chemicals
sections.text:
Ferric chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3 6H2O), ferrous sulfate heptahydrate (FeSO4 7H2O), halloysite nanotubes (HNTs), ammonium hydroxide (NH4OH, 25%, w/w), (3-aminopropyl)-triethoxysilane (APTES), sodium dihydrogen phosphate, disodium
hydrogen phosphate and N-(3-(dimethylamino)-propyl)-N0-ethylcarbodiimide hydrochloride (EDC) were purchased from SigmaAldrich. N-hydroxysuccinimide (NHS) was obtained from Alfa Aesar. Analytical grade of toluene was used as received without further purification. All the solutions were prepared by using bidistilled deionized water (18.2 MV cm) unless otherwise mentioned. The water used throughout the experiments was purified through a UV treated Rephile water system (Scheme 1).

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis of Fe3O4-HNT nanocomposites
sections.text: The Fe3O4-HNT nanocomposites were synthesized according to the previous report [26]. In brief, 0.5 g of HNTs were dispersed in 200 mL deionized water under sonication for 10 min. The aqueous suspension was heated up to 60 C, and then 1.165 g of FeCl3 6H2O and 0.6 g of FeSO4 7H2O were added to the suspension with vigorous stirring under the nitrogen atmosphere. Afterwards, 20 mL of 8 M NH4OH solution were added dropwisely to precipitate the surface-immobilized Fe2+ and Fe3+ ions. To ensure the full conversion of iron ions to iron oxides, the pH of reaction mixture was maintained at about 11. Finally, the resulting black mixture product was aged at 70 C for 6 h, separated by a magnet and then washed with deionized water repeatedly. The obtained Fe3O4-HNT nanocomposite was dried at 70 C for 12 h.

sections.heading: 2.3. APTES coating on Fe3O4-HNTs
sections.text: The Fe3O4-HNT nanocomposites were prepared by coating APTES onto Fe3O4-HNT surface [25]. The Fe3O4-HNTs were first pre-treated by washing with distilled water and then dried at 100 C for 10 h. APTES, dissolved in dry toluene, was then added into the Fe3O4-HNT suspensions and sonicated for 30min. The suspension was then refluxed at 120 C for 20 h under constant stirring. The solid phase in the resultant mixture was filtered and extensively washed with fresh toluene to remove the excess APTES, dried overnight at 70 C for further use.

sections.heading: 2.4. Synthesis of N-GQDs
sections.text: The N-GQDs were fabricated by dissolving 0.21 g citric acid and 0.18 g urea into 5 mL of bi-distilled deionized water and stirred to form a clear solution. The solution was then transferred into a 20- mL Teflon lined stainless autoclave. The sealed autoclave was heated to 160 C in an oven and kept for additional 4 h. The final product was collected by adding ethanol into the solution and centrifuged at 5,000 rpm for 5 min. The solid can be easily dispersed into water. Then, the N-GQD solution was dialyzed in a 1 kDa dialysis bag for 24 h (dialysate was replaced every 8 h) to remove the unreacted chemicals and preserved in dark at 4 C for further use [27]. GQDs were prepared by using the same procedure mentioned above except the addition of urea.

sections.heading: 2.5. Fabrication of GQDs and N-GQDs on APTES coated Fe3O4-HNTs
sections.text:
The GQDs/N-GQD anchored Fe3O4-HNT nanocomposites were prepared through the reaction of carboxylic acid group of N-GQDs with the amine group of APTES coated Fe3O4-HNT via the standard EDC/NHS reaction [28]. Briefly, 4 mg of EDC and 5 mg of NHS were added into 10 mL of as-prepared N-GQDs solutions under vigorous stirring. APTES coated Fe3O4-HNTs were then added to the solution and reacted for 4 h under stirring. The solid phase in the resultant mixture was filtered, washed with DI water to remove the
Scheme 1. Schematic illustration of fabrication of N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs and their supercapacitor applications.
unattached N-GQDs, and then dried overnight at 70 C for further use.

sections.heading: 2.6. Characterization of N-GQDs, Fe3O4-HNTs and N-GQD@Fe3O4HNTs
sections.text:
The morphology as well as size of Fe3O4 and HNT based nanocomposites were characterized using JEOL JEM-ARM200F transmission electron microscope (TEM) and JEOL JEM-2010 highresolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) at 300 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed with an ESCA Ulvac-PHI 1600 photoelectron spectrometer from physical electronics using Al-Ka radiation photon energy at 1486.6 0.2 eV, X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded using Bruker D8 Xray diffractometer with Ni-filtered Cu-Ka radiation (l = 1.5406 Å), and the Fourier transformation infrared (FTIR) spectra of samples were determined by using a Horiba FT720 spectrophotometer to confirm the functionalization. Raman spectra of N-GQDs were determined by Burker Senterra micro-Raman spectrometer equipped with an Olympus BX 51 microscope and DU420-OE
CCD camera. Elemental analysis of N-GQDs was carried out using an organic elemental analyzer (VarioEL III). The thermal properties of HNT and Fe3O4 based nanomaterials were examined by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) using Mettler Toledo DSC/TGA 3+ Star system in air. Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms were determined at 77 K using Micromeritics ASAP 2020 analyzer. Prior to the adsorption isotherm, the samples were outgassed under a high vacuum at 90 C. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller method was utilized to calculate the specific surface areas and pore volumes of Fe3O4-HNTs, APTES coated Fe3O4-HNTs and NGQD@Fe3O4-HNTs.

sections.heading: 2.7. Electrochemical Measurements
sections.text:
A conventional three-electrode system was used to perform the electrochemical experiments including cyclic voltammogram (CV), galvanostatic charge/discharge (GCD) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) by using Autolab PGSTAT 302N electrochemical test system (Metrohm Autolab B.V.). Carbon paper
electrode was used as a working electrode. The 85 wt% NGQD@Fe3O4-HNT, 10 wt% carbon black and 5 wt% Nafion were mixed to form a homogeneous paste and 0.5–1.5 mg of active materials were then drop-casted onto carbon paper to form the working electrodes for two and three electrode systems. In addition, Ag/AgCl and platinum foil were used as the reference and counter electrode, respectively, in the presence of 1 M Na2SO4 as the electrolyte. The specific capacitance was calculated from the discharge curve based on their standard equation, and the energy and power densities for Ragone plot were obtained from the twoelectrode system.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of N-GQDs
sections.text:
The morphology as well as particle size distribution of N-doped GQDs was first identified by TEM and high-resolution TEM images. As shown in Fig. 1a, the as-prepared N-doped GQDs are homogenous in size and well-dispersed. The histograms of Ndoped GQDs are narrow size distributed and the particle sizes are in the range of 4–10 nm with mean diameter of 7 nm. From the HRTEM image (Fig. 1b), the N-doped GQDs are nearly spherical
particles with the lattice spacing of 0.21 nm, which corresponds to (100) plane of graphitic carbon. This result clearly indicates the successful formation of sp2 hybridised carbon nanostructures [29].
The FT-IR spectra of N-GQDs shows a broad absorption band at 3000–3500 cm 1 (Fig. 1c), which can be assigned as the stretching vibrations of O H and N H bonds. Since urea was used to serve as the N source for doping, this result reflects the fact that there are abundant amine and hydroxyl groups on the surface of N-GQDs. The peak at 1667 cm 1 is the vibrational absorption band of C¼O in COOH [29] and the peaks occurring at 1575 and 1401 cm 1 belong to the bending vibrations of C¼C and C N [27]. These oxygenated and nitrogenous functional groups may result in the good hydrophilic surface property of N-GQDs. In addition, the elemental analysis results show that the as-prepared N-GQDs contain 39.2%, 13.9% and 6.8% of carbon (C), nitrogen (N) and hydrogen (H), clearly indicating the successful doping of N atoms into the lattice of GQDs during the hydrothermal procedures. Furthermore, Raman spectroscopy was further used to identify the change in graphitic structure of as-prepared N-GQDs. Fig. 1d shows the disordered (D) and crystalline (G) bands at 1378 and 1575 cm 1, respectively. The D band is related to the presence of sp3 defects, while the G band is the in-plane vibration of sp2 carbon [27]. The ratio of the intensity (ID/IG) of these characteristic bands can be used to correlate the
ributed N-GQDs, (c) FTIR and (d) Raman spectra of N-GQDs.
structural property of carbon and the ID/IG value of 0.88 is obtained for N-GQDs, which means that the as-prepared N-doped GQDs are crystalline and graphitic nanomaterials [27].

sections.heading: 3.2. Morphology and structural characterization of N-GQD@Fe3O4HNTs
sections.text:
To fabricate the N-GQD anchored Fe3O4-HNT nanocomposites, Fe3O4-HNTs were prepared by the co-precipitation of Fe3O4 in the presence of HNTs. Fig. S1 (see Supplementary data) shows the TEM image of Fe3O4-HNT nanocomposites. The addition of Fe3O4 nanoparticles slightly changes the HNT surface structure to uneven. In addition, the Fe3O4 nanoparticles are attached on the surface of HNTs and the diameters of Fe3O4 nanoparticles is in the range of 15–20 nm. The attachment of Fe3O4 nanoparticles on the surface of HNTs could be attributed to the electrostatic interaction and physisorption, which is in good agreement with the results obtained from a previous work which used co-precipitation method for the preparation of diatomite-supported magnetite nanoparticles [30].
To anchor the N-GQDs onto Fe3O4-HNT surface, APTES was first coated onto the surface of Fe3O4-HNTs (APTES-coated Fe3O4-HNTs)
and then N-GQDs were attached onto the surface of APTES-coated Fe3O4-HNTs in the presence of EDC/NHS. As the N-GQDs contain plenty of carboxylic functional groups, the COOH groups of NGQDs can quickly react with amino groups of APTES-coated Fe3O4HNTs to form amide bond, resulting in the intimate attachment of N-GQDs onto the surface of Fe3O4-HNTs. The surface morphology of N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs shown in Fig. 2a to c clearly indicates that N-GQDs are homogeneously distributed and condensed onto the Fe3O4-HNTs surface. Two types of the fringes for N-GQDs and Fe3O4 are also deciphered and the distances of 0.21 and 0.26 nm clearly matches the characteristic lattice plane of N-GQD (Fig. 2d) [29] and Fe3O4 (Fig. 2e) [31], respectively, indicating the successful attachment of N-GQDs on the surface of APTES coated Fe3O4-HNTs.
Fig. 3a shows the XRD patterns of Fe3O4-HNT based nanomaterials. The XRD patterns of HNTs show the prominent peaks at 12.15 , 20.11 , 24.60 and 35.07 2u due to the nanocrystalline nature of Al and Si oxides [JCPDS 29-1487] [32]. In addition, peaks appearing at 30.32 , 35.49 , 43.26 , 57.20 and 62.87 2u can be attributed to the (220), (311), (400), (511) and (440) phases of Fe3O4 [JCPDS 19-0629] [33]. After the coating with APTES, no change in peak positions is noted. However, a slight increase in relative intensity is observed, presumably attributed to the well dispersion
of Fe3O4-HNTs after APTES coating. A broad hump over 29 2u appears when N-GQDs are anchored onto APTES-coated Fe3O4HNTs [34], confirming the incorporation of N-GQDs in the asprepared hybrid nanomaterials.
The change in functional groups of Fe3O4-HNT based nanomaterials including the as prepared Fe3O4-HNTs, APTES-coated Fe3O4-HNTs and N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs was investigated by FTIR. As illustrated in Fig. 3b, the as-prepared Fe3O4-HNT nanocomposites show an Al-O-Si peak at 536 cm 1 with a shoulder peak at 575 cm 1,which is mainly due to the Fe-O vibration in Fe3O4. The presence of magnetic Fe3O4 nanoparticles can be evidenced by the two strong absorption bands at 632 and 585 cm 1 [35]. The adsorption bands at 1113 and 1048 cm 1 are the characteristic peaks of Si–O H and Si–O–Si groups, respectively, which confirms the appearance of APTES on the surface of Fe3O4-HNTs. The anchoring propyl group from APTES is confirmed by the C H stretching vibration at 2900 cm 1 [35]. The broad peak appeared over 3360–3450 cm 1 is the contribution from the stretching vibration signals of hydroxyl (–OH) and amine (–NH2) functional groups in APTES moieties. It is important to note that the vibration of NH2 from the as-prepared N-GQDs is in the region similar to that of APTES-coated Fe3O4–HNTs and no additional peak from NGQDs is observed in the FTIR spectrum. All these observations indicate the successful incorporation of N-GQDs over APTESFe3O4-HNTs.
Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of Fe3O4-HNTs, APTEScoated Fe3O4-HNTs and N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs was performed between 30–800 C in air. As shown in Fig. 3c, Fe3O4–HNTs show a slight decrease in weight from 30 to 180 C, which is attributed to the loss of surface-adsorbed and interstitial water molecules. A
sharp weight loss in the range of 400–510 C is mainly due to the decomposition of labile hydroxyl groups and trace organic contents in Fe3O4-HNTs [25,36]. The loading of Fe3O4 was further calculated from the sharp weight loss between Fe3O4–HNTs and bare HNTs in the temperature range of 450–800 C [26]. It is clear that the weight losses for Fe3O4-HNTs and bare HNTs are 6.9 and 9.9 wt%, respectively, which correspond to 47 wt% of Fe3O4 in Fe3O4–HNTs. This value is almost similar to the weight ratio (1:1) of HNTs and Fe3O4 used for preparation of Fe3O4-HNTs, depicitng that most of the produced Fe3O4 particles are attached onto the surface of HNTs. Different from the thermal property of Fe3O4-HNTs, APTES-coated Fe3O4-HNTs exhibit a slow weight loss from 30 to 150 C following by a distinct decrease at 300–510 C, which is mainly attributed to the pyrolysis of thermally labile oxygenated and hydrogenated functional groups [25]. It is noteworthy that APTES-coated Fe3O4-HNTs show a total weight loss of 20 wt%, which is higher than that of the as-prepared Fe3O4-HNTs. The increased weight loss during the thermal treatment confirms the presence of APTES in nanocomposites. Similar to the TGA curve of APTES-coated Fe3O4-HNTs, a continuous decrease in weight from 30 to 800 C for N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs with a total weight loss of 21.4 wt% is clearly observed. An additional weight loss of 1.4 wt% is obtained when compares to that of APTES-coated Fe3O4-HNTs, which corresponds to the added amounts of N-GQDs onto APTEScoated Fe3O4-HNT nanocomposites.
Fig. 3d displays the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions. All the Fe3O4-HNT based nanomaterials exhibit a type IV isotherm with distinct type H3 hysteresis loop in the relative pressure (P/P0) of 0.7–0.95. This type of isotherm is an important characteristic of capillary condensation in mesopores
[37]. The specific surface area of as-prepared Fe3O4-HNTs is determined to be 39 m2g 1, which is lower than that of HNTs (64 m2g 1). This decrease is mainly attributed to the deposition of Fe3O4 nanoparticles on the surface of HNTs. After coating with APTES, the specific surface area again decreases to 29.2 m2g 1 and the average pore diameter also decreases from 21.1 nm for Fe3O4HNTs to 18.3 nm for APTES-coated Fe3O4-HNTs. The presence of aminopropyl groups of APTES would cover the surface and pore channels of as-prepared Fe3O4-HNTs, and subsequently results in the decrease in specific surface area and pore diameters. The functionalization of APTES-coated Fe3O4-HNT with N-GQDs further decreases the surface area and pore size to 27.4 m2g 1
and 16.2 nm, respectively, confirming the successful loading of NGQDs.
Fig. 4 shows the XPS of full survey spectra of the Fe3O4-based nanocomposites and deconvoluted Fe 2p and N 1 s peaks of APTEScoated Fe3O4-HNTs before and after the addition of N-GQDs. The survey scan of as-prepared Fe3O4-HNTs clearly shows the characteristic peaks of Al 2p (75.1 eV), Si 2p (103.1 eV), Al 2 s (119.6 eV), Si 2 s (153.4 eV), C 1 s (284.4 eV), O 1 s (531.6 eV) and Fe (711.5 and 725.1 eV) (Fig. 4a). In addition, no N 1 s peak is observed in the survey scan of Fe3O4-HNTs. After the functionalization with APTES and N-GQDs, the N 1 s peak appears at around 400 eV appears and the peak intensity of C 1 s increases, clearly indicating the successful attachment of APTES and N-GQDs onto Fe3O4-HNT surfaces [38,39].
The peak deconvolution of Fe 2p spectra was further performed (Fig. 4b). The characteristic peaks of Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 centered at 711.5 and 725.1 eV, respectively, confirm the formation of Fe3O4 in the composites. The deconvoluted N 1 s spectra of APTES coated Fe3O4-HNTs and N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs shown in Fig. 4c and d, respectively, represent the significant change in N-H (399.5 eV)
and C-N (401.05 eV) peaks [40]. The peak intensity of C-N increases from APTES-coated Fe3O4-HNTs to N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs, which is mainly attributed to the contribution of amide linkage from the reaction of NH2 of APTES with COOH of N-GQDs.

sections.heading: 3.3. Electrochemical performance of N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs
sections.text:
To evaluate the electrochemical properties of the NGQD@Fe3O4-HNTs, cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements are carried out in 1 M Na2SO4 solution in a potential window of 0–1 V versus Ag/AgCl at various scan rates ranging from 5 to 100 mV s 1. As shown in Fig. 5a, the CV curves of N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs exhibit quasi-rectangular in shape, indicating a remarkably capacitive behaviour. In addition, the curves retain their shape at all scan rates and no obvious shape change or distortion is observed among the CV curves when the scan rate increases from 5 to 100 mV s 1, depicting that the N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNT nanocomposites possess superior rate capability and excellent electrochemical reversibility. The N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs show excellent capacitive behaviour and the specific capacitance is 370 F g 1 at a fixed scan rate of 5 mV s 1
(Fig. 5b). It is also noted that the specific capacitance of NGQD@Fe3O4-HNTs decreases gradually upon the increase in scan rate and the specific capacitance decreases to 210 F g 1 when the scan rate increases to 100 mV s 1. Several studies have used Fe3O4based nanomaterials for supercapacitor application and the specific capacitances of 139 F g 1 at 0.5 A g 1 for Fe3O4-carbon composite [35] and 202.6 F g 1 at 10 mV s 1 for Fe3O4-oxidized activated carbon [41,42] were obtained, which clearly indicating the excellence of N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs nanocomposites used in this study.
Several studies have reported that the Fe3O4 could exhibit pseudocapacitive behaviour in the potential range of 1–0 V [20–
22,24]. Fig. S2 (see Supplementary data) shows the CV curves of NGQD@Fe3O4-HNTs in the negative potential window of 1–0 V at various scan rates of 5–100 mV s 1. It is clear that the CV curves in the negative potential window distort obviously and the specific capacitances are only in the range of 45–87 F g 1 at 5–100 mV s 1, which are less than those in the positive potential window of 0–1 V (Fig. 5b). The low specific capacitance of N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs in the negative potential window is mainly attributed to the fact that Fe3O4 and HNTs are mainly employed as the supporting matrix for N-GQDs. To further identify the role of N-GQDs in electrochemical performance of N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs, the specific capacitance of individual component in the nanocomposites were examined and compared. As shown in Fig. S3 (see Supplementary data), the specific capacitance of HNTs, as-prepared Fe3O4, Fe3O4-HNTs and N-GQD@Fe3O4 are 15, 76, 97 and 142 F g 1, respectively at 5 mV s 1, which are much lower than that of N-GQDs@Fe3O4-HNTs nanocomposite (370 F g 1). These results clearly indicate that the addition of N-GQDs onto Fe3O4-HNTs can significantly enhance the electrochemical performance of Fe3O4-HNT based nanomaterials in the positive potential window of 0–1 V for supercapacitor applications.
The capacitance of as-prepared N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs was evaluated as well by using the galvanostatic charge/discharge measurement. Fig. 5c shows the galvanostatic charge/discharge curves of N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNT nanocomposites at the current density range of 0.5–10 A g 1. The charging and discharging cycles at various current densities are rather symmetric, demonstrating the excellent capacitive characteristic and high coulombic efficiency of the ideal capacitor [43]. The specific capacitance is calculated to be 418 F g 1 at the current density of 0.5 A g 1 and maintains at 130 F g 1 at a scan rate of 10 A g 1, depicting the good rate capability of N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs (Fig. 5d). In addition, the IR
drop is positively proportional to the current density and the IR drops at all the current densities are all < 0.3 V (Fig. S4, see Supplementary data), indicating the fast I–V response and low internal resistance of N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs [44,45].
The cyclic voltammetry and galvanostatic charge/discharge of N-GQDs@Fe3O4-HNT nanocomposites are also performed in alkaline solutions using 1 M KOH as the electrolyte. As shown in Fig. S5 (see Supplementary data), both the CV and GQD curves of NGQD@Fe3O4-HNTs in neutral and alkaline solutions are similar. However, the CV curves of N-GQDs@Fe3O4-HNT nanocomposites in neutral Na2SO4 electrolyte show more ideal rectangular shapes than those in 1 M KOH electrolyte in the potential window of 0–1 V. In addition, the specific capacitance of N-GQDs@Fe3O4-HNT nanocomposites in alkaline solutions are in the range of 87– 175 F g 1 (Table S1, see Supplementary data), which are lower than those in neutral Na2SO4 electrolyte (299–416 F g 1). These results clearly indicate that N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs in neutral Na2SO4 electrolyte can exhibit better electrochemical performance than that in 1 M KOH solution. The superior electrochemical performance of N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs in neutral electrolyte is mainly attributed to the improved conductivity and rapid electron and electrolyte ions transport. HNTs are flexible confinement materials to support Fe3O4 and N-GQDs, which can minimize the agglomeration of Fe3O4 nanoparticles and increase the surface area to improve the accessible capacitance. Additionally, no redox peaks are observed on CV curves, indicating that the charge/discharge processes of the active material (N-GQDs) is carried out at a pseudo-constant rate over the potential window used in this study.
The doping of nitrogen atoms to GQDs makes the nanocomposites more electroactive in comparison with the bare GQDs. Fig. S6 (see Supplementary data) shows the electrochemical performance of N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs and GQD@Fe3O4-HTNs. Both
the CV and GCD curves of GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs are similar to those of N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs. However, the GQD@Fe3O4-HNT nanocomposites show the specific capacitance of 270 F g 1 at 1 A g 1, which is lower than that of N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs (303 F g 1). In addition, the specific capacitances of GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs in all the current density ranges are all lower than those of N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs (Table S2, see Supplementary data), clearly depicting the superior electrochemical performance of N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs to GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs. It is noteworthy that the specific capacitance of N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs obtained in this study is also much higher
than those of Fe3O4 and MnO2 decorated graphene nanomaterials, which could achieve capacitance of 220–368 F g 1 at the current density of 1–2.5 A g 1 [24,44,46]. A previous study has used Fe3O4/ rGO nanocomposite as the electrode material and found that specific capacitance was 220 F g 1 at 0.5 A g 1 [44]. In this study, the surface functionalization of naturally available HNTs with Fe3O4 and N-GQDs for supercapacitor application is well explored and the specific capacitances of 418–204 F g 1 at 0.5–2 A g 1 prove that the N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNT nanocomposites are superior electroactive anode materials for supercapacitor applications.
The inset shows charge/discharge curve of the N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs in the potential
The novel structure of N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs provides large surfaces and good conductivity, which enhance the chargedischarge process to achieve the expected high specific capacitance and high rate performance. The one-dimensional mesoporous character of HNTs decorated with Fe3O4 and N-GQDs provide efficient channels for ions and electrons transport, and subsequently give rise to the faster kinetics as well as result in high charge/discharge capacities. Several modification methods including the carbonization of negatively charged external surface with chitosan and the addition of cationic surfactants to obtain the hydrophobic shell have been attempted to improve the electrochemical performance of HNTs [47,48]. In this study, the addition of Fe3O4 can effectively shorten the diffusion paths of electrons and electrolyte ions by providing nanodimensional electrical contact sites for fast electron transfer, while N-GQDs provide abundantly accessible electroactive sites to rapidly transport electrons during the charge-discharge processes to benefit the rate capability and power density at large charge/discharge current, which can compensate the low conductivity of Fe3O4- HNTs. Therefore, the N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNT anode materials exert the advantage and alleviate the defects of transition metal oxides.
The energy and power densities of N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNT nanomaterials are calculated based on the galvanostatic chargedischarge results from the two electrode cells at 0.5–10 A g 1
and the Ragone plot is shown in Fig. 6a. The N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs deliver excellent energy and power densities of 29 Wh kg 1 and 0.25 kW kg 1 at 0.5 A g 1, respectively, and still can maintain the high energy density of 10.4 Wh kg 1 with power density of 5.2 kW kg 1 at a current density of 10 A g 1. These results demonstrate that the high specific capacitance and energy density of the N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNT nanocomposites promise the better electrode performance for practical applications. The cycling stability of supercapacitor is an important parameter to evaluate the potentially practical applications of electrode materials. Fig. 6b summarizes the temporal evolution of specific capacitance of NGQD@Fe3O4-HNTs over consecutive charge-discharge cycles at a current density of 1 A g 1. The device shows a high capacitance of 303 F g 1 initially and retains more than 82% of its initial capacitance after 3,000 charge/discharge cycles. No obvious
decrease in capacitance is observed during the cycling period, indicating that the electroactive N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNT anode materials have a good long-term electrochemical stability. The inset of Fig. 6b shows the charge/discharge curve of N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs in the potential window of 0–1 V at 1 A g 1. The charge/discharge curves between the first and last 5 cycles are almost unchanged, which indicates the highly electrochemical stability of NGQD@Fe3O4-HNTs during the charge/discharge processes. In addition, the cycling stability of as-prepared Fe3O4-HNTs was examined. As shown in Fig. S7 (see Supplementary data), the initial specific capacitance of Fe3O4-HNTs is 168 F g 1 at a current density of 1 A g 1 and only 45.6% of the initial capacitance can be retained after 3,000 cycles. The superior cycling stability of N-GQD@Fe3O4HNTs to the Fe3O4-HNTs and other GQD-based electrodes [49,50] is mainly attributed to the strong interaction between the Fe3O4 and N-GQD. The N-GQDs contain hydrophilic functional groups and the covalent bonding of N-GQDs onto the metal oxide surfaces of Fe3O4-HNTs enhances the cycle life along with the increase in specific capacitance. The doping of nitrogen in GQDs can also provide more active sites to strengthen the electrical conductivity, resulting in the enhancement of structural stability of N-GQDs during the cycling test. The little decay in specific capacitance during cycling is mainly due to the mechanical expansion/ contraction of electrode material by insertion/exertion of electrolyte ions [51].
To further illustrate the merits of using N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs as the electrode material, electrochemical impedance spectra were used to elucidate the electrochemical property of electrode materials. Fig. 7 shows the Nyquist plot of Fe3O4-based nanomaterials including N-GQD@Fe3O4, Fe3O4-HNTs support and NGQD@Fe3O4-HNTs nanocomposites. The high-frequency intercept on the X-axis represents the equivalent series resistance (Rs), which associates with the sum of the electrolyte solution resistance, the intrinsic resistance of active material and the contact resistance at the electrode–electrolyte interface [52]. The charge transfer resistance of electrode (Rct) can be calculated from the diameter of semicircle in the high frequency region, while the straight line at low frequency represents the diffusion behaviour of ions in the electrode pores. The steep slope of straight line
represents an ideal capacitive behaviour with the rapid diffusion of ions in electrolyte [53]. The Rs values of N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs, NGQD@Fe3O4 and Fe3O4-HNTs are 3.1, 3.0 and 3.3 V, respectively, which means that the resistance of electrode-electrolyte interfaces of these electrode materials is similar. However, the NGQD@Fe3O4-HNTs exhibit a lower Rct value of 0.68 V compares with that of Fe3O4-HNTs (1.01 V) and N-GQD@Fe3O4 (0.72 V). These results clearly indicate that the anchoring of N-GQDs can enhance the electrical conductivity and ion diffusion behaviour, resulting in the high electrochemical performance of NGQD@Fe3O4-HNT nanocomposite for supercapacitor.
In this study, the N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs nanocomposites have shown the superior electrochemical performance. When N-GQDs have immobilized onto the surface of APTES-coated Fe3O4-HNTs via EDC/NHS chemistry, the synergistic effect between N-GQDs and Fe3O4-HNTs significantly enhances the electrochemical performance and the capacitance obtained are much higher than the most reported GQD and Fe3O4–based nanomaterials [7,49]. Several plausible possibilities can be accounted for this enhancement. Firstly, the aligned Fe3O4-HNTs facilitate the ion diffusion from electrolytes to N-GQDs more readily, making the possibly full use of electroactive materials. Secondly, the intimate interaction between N-GQDs and Fe3O4-HNTs provides the high conductivity benefit to shorten the ion diffusion pathways as well as to decrease the charge-transfer resistances, leading to the rapid transport of electrons to enhance the specific capacitance. Meanwhile, the synergistic effect results in the better cycling stability of the NGQD@Fe3O4-HNTs. Finally, the N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs can serve as the platform to withstand the strain relaxation and mechanical deformation, preventing the electrode materials from swelling and shrinking during the insertion/disinsertion processes of the counter ions. Therefore, the as-prepared N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs exhibit enhanced capacitive performances for supercapacitor applications.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: In this study, we have demonstrated an effective strategy to significantly boost the capacitive properties of N-GQD@Fe3O4based electrodes in the presence of neutral aqueous electrolytes by intimately anchoring N-GQDs onto Fe3O4-HNT surfaces. The NGQDs with mean diameter of 7 nm can offer abundantly accessible electroactive sites for rapid electrons and electrolyte ions transport as well as enhance electrical conductivity of Fe3O4-HNTs. The NGQD@Fe3O4-HNT nanocomposites exhibit superior electrochemical performance and a high specific capacitance of 418 F g 1 is obtained at a current density of 0.5 A g 1 in neutral electrolyte solution. In addition, the nanocomposites exhibit excellent energy density of 10.4–29 Wh kg 1 with high power capability of and 0.25–5.2 kW kg 1. The nanocomposites also exhibit good stability with 82% retention of the original capacitance after 3,000 chargedischarge cycle at 1 A g 1. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report on using N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs as the promising anode materials for supercapacitor applications. The N-GQDs can significantly enhance the energy density, while Fe3O4-HNTs provide an efficient matrix to absorb the mechanical stress during cycling along with excess sites for charge storage as well as shorten the diffusion paths of electrons and electrolyte ions by providing nano-dimensional contact sites for fast electron transfer.

sections.text: Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j. electacta.2017.06.002.

metadata.abstractText: The development of robust and low cost electrode materials with superior electrochemical properties has been a subject of focus on energy storage devices. Herein, the development of N-doped graphene quantum dots (N-GQDs) deposited on Fe3O4-halloysite nanotubes (Fe3O4-HNTs) as active anode materials has been established for supercapacitor applications. The Fe3O4 nanoparticles synthesised by coprecipitation have been in-situ deposited on HNT surfaces following by the coating of (3aminopropyl)-triexthoxysilane to anchor 4–10 nm N-GQDs via the formation of amide linkage. The N-GQD@Fe3O4-HNTs exhibits a high specific capacitance of 418 F g 1 and maintains good rate capability in neutral electrolyte solutions. In addition, the anode materials show excellent electrochemical performance with energy and power densities of 10.4–29 W h kg 1 and 0.25–5.2 kW kg , respectively. Such excellent electrochemical features can be attributed to the synergistic contribution from individual components. The Fe3O4-HNTs provide 1-dimensional matrix to shorten the diffusion path of electrons and electrolyte ions as well as to absorb the mechanical stress during cycling along with excess sites for charge storage, while N-GQDs offer abundantly accessible electroactive sites for rapid electrons and electrolyte ions transport as well as enhance electrical conductivity of Fe3O4-HNTs. Results obtained in this study clearly demonstrate that metal oxide-HNTs are promising support to anchor N-GQDs nanomaterials as the high performance anode materials for next generation of energy storage devices with high energy and power densities. © 2017 Elsevier Ltd.
